title: Research
text:
Drivers of population cycles from predators to pathogens


Non-Native herbivores and sagebrush plant community condition


Evaluating annual grass cover at fuel breaks in the sagebrush biome


Fishers and wildfire in Yosemite National Park


Climate change responses of mammals in the American West


Parasite and pathogen impacts on marmot alarm calling behavior


Mammal community richness and coyote-human activity overlap in urban nature preserves


Fieldwork for ecological research projects
I have had non-authorship roles on ecological research projects across a variety of taxa and ecosystems. I have worked with mountain yellow-legged frogs, nurse sharks, carrion beetles, American pika, among others.

title: About Me
text: I am a PhD student in the Twining Applied Quantitative Ecology Lab at Oregon State University in the department of Fisheries, Wildlife, and Conservation Sciences. Previously, I was a Presidential Management Fellow at the US Geological Survey working on applied wildlife research in the sagebrush biome of the American West. I completed both my master’s and bachelor’s degrees in the Department of Ecology and Evolutionary Biology with an additional specialization in computer science and geographic information science at the University of Colorado Boulder, where I was an Astronaut Scholar. I have conducted ecological research with local non-profits, state wildlife agencies, federal land management and wildlife agencies, and academia. In addition to research, I enjoy fishing, mountain biking, trail running, rock and ice climbing, surfing, skiing, and most other things outdoors.
